newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: MANSFIELD REVIEW FLOODED
More than ten thousand submissions have been received for the review of the ABC, being headed by Bob Mansfield.
Last's Friday's deadline was extended, after people weren't able to get through on the fax machine.
A spokesman says any letter or fax that reaches the review office by the close of business on Friday will be accepted.
NSW REBUTTAL OF FAST TRAIN DELAY CLAIMS
The New South Wales government has flick-passed the blame for delays in the development of the high speed rail link between Sydney and Canberra back to the Federal and ACT governments.
Federal Transport Minister, John Sharp, yesterday accused the New South Wales government of stalling the link, meaning it won't be in place for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.
But Mr Sharp's New South Wales counterpart, Brian Langton, says his government was the first to commit funds to the link's feasibility study.
And Mr Langton says the ACT government deferred the steering committee in mid-May, then reported in June that its officials hadn't been able to complete tasks they'd been allotted.
KENNETT: ACTU LEADERSHIP TERMINAL
Victoria's Premier, Jeff Kennett, says the ACTU is in danger of self-destructing.
Mr Kennett's told a Melbourne business breakfast the ACTU leadership should have accepted responsibility for the Canberra Parliament House riots.
The Premier says, by refusing to do so, President Jennie George and Secretary Bill Kelty have ensured their leadership is terminal.
OFFICIAL INTEREST RATES UNCHANGED
The final meeting of the Reserve Bank board with Bernie Fraser as chairman has taken no action on monetary policy, despite speculation official interest rates would be cut.
Predictions the central bank would cut official rates at its monthly board meeting yesterday were hosed down with the release of figures showing a strong increase in retail spending in July.
Citibank's Stephen Koukoulas says he wasn't surprised this morning's deadline for a monetary policy announcement passed without a word from the Reserve Bank.
NETWORK TO COMBAT GRAFFITI TIPPIED
The first national conference on the control of graffiti has been told action to combat graffiti vandalism has until now happened at a state level, with little sharing of information and ideas.
West Australian Premier, Richard Court, told the Perth conference he's confident it will result in a national network to target graffiti.
Mr Court says W-A is acknowledged as a leader in developing strategies to reduce the level of graffiti, which has fallen by 50 per cent in the state since 1993.
